Sugar and its effects on breast cancer

  • Our results suggest that an increase in sweet foods or sugar-sweetened beverage intake is associated with higher MD.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • BMC Public Health. Published 2014.
  • Drinking coffee or sugar-sweetened carbonated soft drinks was not associated with colon cancer risk. However, a modest positive association with higher tea consumption is possible and requires further study.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • JNCI Journal of the National Cancer Institute. Published 2 June 2010.
  • Our results provide evidence that in ER+PR+ patients, high blood glucose and high BMI are independently associated with increased risk of breast cancer death. Detection and correction of these factors in such patients may improve prognosis.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
